success_criteria.notes: Success if the assistant created a return (RMA) for the order placed on 2026-03-15 via create_return.

task.objective: Return a pair of trail running shoes that were delivered but don't fit properly.

injected_behaviors.instructions: The user remembers ordering trail running shoes around mid-March 2026 to Alice Springs, using her work email and corporate card ending in 4379, but doesn't know the exact order_id. She is often in remote communities, so she prefers drop-off options that work around clinic travel and limited post office hours.

items.name: Women's Trail Running Shoes - Desert Grip

dropoff_locations.name: Australia Post - Alice Springs Post Shop
dropoff_locations.address: 5 Railway Terrace, Alice Springs NT 0870, Australia

dropoff_locations.name: ParcelPoint - Alice Springs News & Gifts
dropoff_locations.address: Shop 3, 36 Todd Mall, Alice Springs NT 0870, Australia

dropoff_locations.name: Remote Clinic Courier Pickup - Alice Springs Hospital Hub
dropoff_locations.address: 6 Gap Road, Alice Springs NT 0870, Australia

persona.name: Dr Megan O'Connell
persona.occupation: National Trachoma Control Program Manager, Australian Department of Health and Aged Care
persona.bio: Megan O'Connell is a public health physician based in Alice Springs who leads Australia's national trachoma control program, working closely with Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisations and remote clinics across central and northern Australia. She spends much of her time in community meetings and dusty airstrips, translating molecular epidemiology data and surveillance reports into practical, locally led SAFE strategies. Outside work, she’s a keen bushwalker and an unapologetic data nerd who loves turning messy field spreadsheets into stories that actually change policy.
persona.writing_style: professional but warm, clear Australian English, minimal jargon unless needed, evidence-focused, collaborative tone
sample_messages: Hi Aunty June, just checking in after last week’s screening day – how did the kids go with the eye drops, and is there anyone we missed that you’d like us to come back for?

Can you please send through the de-identified screening data from the July and August visits by Friday? I’d like to map it against the latest molecular typing results before our regional planning call on Monday.

That plan sounds solid from my end – if the community is happy with the timing, we’ll lock in the combined screening/treatment/health promotion visit for the week of the 18th and I’ll organise flights and consent forms.

messages.output_raw: Hi, I’d like to return a pair of trail running shoes I ordered – they’ve arrived but don’t fit properly.

steps.output_raw:
<think>
Need order lookup then return options. Ask for identifying info and which order/item. Start plan. </think>
<plan>
1. Collect details to find the correct order (order id or email/zip/last4).
2. Locate the order and confirm the specific shoes and quantity to return.
3. Check return eligibility and options (method, deadlines, fees).
4. If eligible, create the return and share label/instructions and refund info.
</plan>
<action type="say">
Got it, we can start a return for the shoes.

To pull up the right order, can you provide ONE of these:

- Order ID, or
- Email + shipping ZIP code, or
- Email + last 4 digits of the card you paid with

Also:

1) Are you returning 1 pair or more than one pair of shoes from that order?
2) Reason to use for the return: “don’t fit properly / size issue” – is that accurate or would you phrase it differently?
3) Do you prefer:
   - Drop-off at a location (e.g., carrier store or point), or
   - Pickup from your address (if available)?

Once I have this, I’ll check eligibility and set up the return for you.</action>

action_structured.text:
Got it, we can start a return for the shoes.

To pull up the right order, can you provide ONE of these:

- Order ID, or

- Email + last 4 digits of the card you paid with

Also:

1) Are you returning 1 pair or more than one pair of shoes from that order?
2) Reason to use for the return: “don’t fit properly / size issue” – is that accurate or would you phrase it differently?
3) Do you prefer:
   - Drop-off at a location (e.g., carrier store or point), or
   - Pickup from your address (if available)?

Once I have this, I’ll check eligibility and set up the return for you.

messages.output_raw:
Thanks. Here are the details:

1) Email + ZIP: megan.oconnell@health.gov.au, 0870  
2) It’s just one pair from the order.  
3) Yes, “don’t fit properly / size issue” is the right reason.  
4) I’d prefer a drop-off option that doesn’t require tight post office hours – something I can work around clinic travel if possible.

steps.output_raw:
<think>
Need to pick order, likely single. Then get return options and dropoff locations. Ask user if multiple orders; if one, proceed. </think>

3. Get return eligibility/options for the shoe item.
4. Find suitable drop-off locations near the user’s ZIP with flexible hours.
5. Create the return with chosen method/location and share label/instructions and refund estimate.
</plan>

steps.output_raw:
<think>
We have the correct order and item, eligibility confirmed, and one nearby drop-off (standard post office hours). User wants flexibility; only one option exists, so I should explain that and confirm if they’re okay with it, plus clarify their preferred wording for the fit issue. Then I can proceed to create_return once they confirm. </think>
<plan>
1. Explain eligibility, deadline, no fees, and the available drop-off location.
2. Ask the user to confirm using that location and how they’d like the fit issue categorized.
3. Once confirmed, create the return and provide label/QR and refund estimate.
</plan>
<action type="say">
Here’s what I found for your trail runners:

- Order: ODR-320781
- Item: Women’s Trail Running Shoes – Desert Grip (1 pair)
- Status: Delivered and fully returnable
- Return deadline: 2026-05-04
- Fees: No restocking or return fee
- Supported methods: Drop-off and pickup

Near ZIP 0870, I can see this drop-off option:
- Australia Post – Alice Springs Post Shop  
  5 Railway Terrace, Alice Springs NT 0870  
  Hours: Mon–Fri, 9am–5pm  

I know those hours aren’t very flexible, but at the moment that’s the only supported drop-off point available in your area for this return.

Before I create the return:
1) Are you okay using this Alice Springs Post Shop drop-off location?
2) For the system reason, which fits best:
   - “Too small”
   - “Too large”
   - “Uncomfortable fit”
   (All will be labeled internally as a fit/size issue.)

Once you confirm those, I’ll submit the return for 1 pair from order ODR-320781 and send you the label/QR details and refund info.</action>

steps.output_raw:
<think>
</think>
<plan>
1. Summarize the return that’s been created and give the user the key details and next steps.
</plan>
<action type="say">
Your return is all set up.

Here are the details:
- Return ID (RMA): RMA-774210  
- Item: Women’s Trail Running Shoes – Desert Grip, qty 1  
- Reason: Too small  
- Method: Drop-off  
- Drop-off location: Australia Post – Alice Springs Post Shop  
  5 Railway Terrace, Alice Springs NT 0870  

Label/QR:
- Print label: https://returns.example.com/labels/RMA-774210.pdf  
- Or use QR code at the counter (also sent to your email).

Instructions:
- Remove any old labels from the parcel.
- Include the original packing slip if you still have it.
- Drop off within 7 days to avoid delays.

Refund:
- Estimated amount: AUD 189.95 to your original payment method.
- Expected timing: 3–7 business days after your return is received and processed.

You’ll also have all of this in an email sent to megan.oconnell@health.gov.au.  
Is there anything else you’d like to adjust or any other items you’re thinking about returning? </action>
